text: The software that is shipped with the LaserPro is buggy and and not very powerful. LaserPro is not compatible with Lightburn - yet - they are working on it. However after several weeks playing with it, I found that with a very simple GCODE header and footer added to the Lightburn configuration file, the LaserPro will (mostly) run with Lightburn. It has a very small spot and is very powerful. It easily cuts 3mm plywood at 225mm/min at 95% power, and engraves literally everything. It has an internal fan that provides air assist, blowing air from the same orifice as the laser, and the lens is recessed in the laser head so smoke does not settle out on the lens. The auto focus works great, and the enclosure with the fan lets you vent the smoke out a window. The video camera takes a bit of careful setup but is extremely useful. When the LaserPro is fully Lightburn compatible it will definitely be the diode laser engraver to buy. My LaserPro is now the one I use for all my projects, and my previous laser engraver (which I was very happy with) sits pretty much idle.

The big thunder we have has like a 3ft √ó 4.5ft cutting area which seems insane, but one thing we have noticed with it is that the laser's cutting power gets weaker as you move away from the source, so you can't really utilize the full cutting area as easily. text: I'd love your opinion on our use case of this vs the Ortur. Was just about to go for the Ortur LM2 Pro when I saw this video. Eithers' most difficult and frequent use case would be for a teacher cutting paper, cardboard, and occasional thin (6mm or less basswood/balsawood) for young student projects. Along with doing engraving for gifts and occasional sales (once or twice a year flea markets, no online shop).  Would a 4" hose and exhaust fan to outside *near* the xTool be enough in a basement shop? I've got preexisting 4" exhausts running for airbrush and resin 3d printers. Or should we really use an enclosure?  Really like the xTool build quality and what seems to be a better laser module with dual diode. "Good enough" software doesn't seem to be a problem since it doesn't need a persistent online connection like glowforge. The big thing that has me hesitating on this xTool is that the Ortur has an optional enclosure, seems to have more reviews, more mods, and more units actually out there in the hands of hobbyists.

text:
Good video, however just about everything you said sketchup cant do.....it can. For one, model using dynamic components. You can not only change sizing on the fly but you can also animate door openings, drawers and check for collisions etc. This is HUGE! You can change material thickness etc. Rendering....well, that depends on what you are trying to accomplish. Sketchup uses companies like VRay and Lumion..... Fusion 360s internal renderer cant compare. That does require an additional software purchase, but being that was a point brought up I assume we are focusing on quality of render potential and Vray simply cant be touched. One huge advantage Sketchup has over Fusion 360 is Layout, the quality and ease of use to create amazing drawings is a big need for me. Again both of these programs are solid, it just depends on what you are doing and what you need. I would not count sketchup out as it is very powerful, and even more so when paired with quality plugins. I do like Fusions CAM capability though, I currently export to Aspire, but 3d shapes would
 be nice to toolpath on screen like that. Thanks for the video!
video: Is Fusion 360 worth learning over Sketchup?

text:
The ORTUR looks like it be good for some DIY 3D printer, with some modifications.

I worked at a place that used a type of plastic powder, in the consistency of baby powder. Wile sitting in it's shaker, it looked like bubbling liquid. Wile in that state, it is sucked up with a positive charge added to it, and sprayed on a metal part with a negative charge, to make the powder paint stick to it. After, it goes into an oven to melt the plastic onto the metal as a covering. Comes in many colors.

If one was to have a table that a slider arm will lay out a thin layer of that powder onto a table, the ORTUR could be use to trace out the shape of one layer to a 3D part. The table would drop by one layer, as the slider arm adds another layer of powder. The ORTUR traces out that next layer, before the table drops again. Repeat, until all layers are complete.

Use a small vac to suck up the unused powder, and you got a 3D part. Trick is, getting the ORTUR to be part of that automated task. Could be make possible with a Raspberry PI I think.

Would prove to be a neat project. And cost vastly less than other 3D printers that do such already costing over 15,000 for a low end 3D printer of that type.

k40 whisperer was a game changer for the k40...i now have built my own 
600x400 co2 laser using the k40 control board, 45w spt laser.....have 
had for 3+ years.....spt makes great tubes.....they are actually tested 
with info like peak power......made motorized bed out of 1x1 steel tube 
and 3d printed parts....total cost was $900....well worth it as its paid
 for itself many times over
